Comment: ~ Always 1. e4 ... 2. f4 ... 3. Nf3 ... (gambits by nature are not fundamentally sound, but when I saw someone using it against me in Afghanistan I fell for the novelty of it! Lively play and it can be beaten.)
~ Will he accept? It's too tempting! Also available is the gambit declined and the gambit accepted.
~ Be advised: Bishops before Knights is a no-no! The c8-g3 diagonal open but easily dismissed.

~  I've decided not concede his Bishop pin on my Knight. This could have been a disastrous decision if he would have caught it (3. ... Qh4+ 4. g2 Qxe4 5. Be2 Qxh1 followed by more self-inlflicted wounds)
~ Breathing easier now. An experienced player would not have lost to me.
~ It would be much better to guard the King's pawn with 4. ... Nc6 (Bishops should be attacking!)
~ I'm cooking up some fried liver. The f7 pawn is on the grill!
~ "Stop kidding yourself. It's too late to Castle Kingside!"
~ Should the King capture? Or just get out of the way!
~ Black is not in bad shape. Not until a fatal decision in the next move.
~ Heaps of trouble in front of your own pawns. Don't play in the traffic if you're the King!
~ Hunting my Knight would be much easier for the pawns.
~ Threatening my Queen won't work. There is no safe place to hide for Black.
~ who would have thought the most important pawns on the Board were at d2, e4, and h5? 8. ... h5 would have prevented this Check!
~ Does it look hopeless for the Queen? No!
~ With Black's Queen and Knight sitting on the Back Rank, the King learns a painful lesson in development. Match Over, 1-0 !
